sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: This report outlines the methodology behind forecasting the outcome of the upcoming Icelandic Parliamentary Elections scheduled for November 30th. The forecast is based on a dynamic linear model implemented in Stan, incorporating polling data over time and adjusting for polling house effects while accounting for overdispersion.

sec.title: Model Specification
sec.p: We model the polling percentages for each political party over time using a dynamic linear model with a Dirichlet-Multinomial observation component. The model captures the evolution of party support and accounts for variations between different polling houses.

TT: Number of time points (dates) at which we have polling data
HH: Number of polling houses
NN: Number of observations (polls)
y_{n,p}yn,p: Count of responses for party pp in poll nn
\Delta_tΔt: The time difference between polls at t-1t−1 and tt in days
\beta_{p,t}βp,t: Latent support for party pp at time tt (for p = 2,\ldots,Pp=2,…,P)
\gamma_{p,h}γp,h: Effect of polling house hh for party pp (for p = 2,\ldots,Pp=2,…,P)
\mu_{\gamma,p}μγ,p: Mean house effect for party pp
\sigma_{\gamma,p}σγ,p: Scale of house effects for party pp
\sigma_pσp: Scale parameter for the random walk of party pp
\phiϕ: Overdispersion parameter

sec.p: Polling house effects are modeled hierarchically to account for systematic biases:

Elections are set to be the first polling house and therefore \gamma_{p,1} = 0γp,1=0.

sec.title: Prior Distributions
sec.p: The priors are specified as follows:

list-item.p: Initial Party Effects: \beta_{p}^{(0)} \sim \mathcal{N}(0, 1)βp(0)∼𝒩(0,1)
Random Walk Innovations: z_{p,t} \sim \mathcal{N}(0, 1)zp,t∼𝒩(0,1)
House Effect Means: \mu_{\gamma,p} \sim \mathcal{N}(0, 1)μγ,p∼𝒩(0,1) with \sum_p \mu_{\gamma,p} \sim \mathcal{N}(0, 1)∑pμγ,p∼𝒩(0,1)
House Effect Scales: \sigma_{\gamma,p} \sim \text{Exponential}(1)σγ,p∼Exponential(1)
Random Walk Scales: \sigma_p \sim \text{Exponential}(1)σp∼Exponential(1)
Overdispersion Parameter Inverse: \phi_{\text{inv}} \sim \text{Exponential}(1)ϕinv∼Exponential(1)

sec.title: Inference
sec.p: Bayesian inference is performed using Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) sampling via Stan. Posterior distributions of the latent variables \beta_{p,t}βp,t and \gamma_{p,h}γp,h are obtained, allowing for probabilistic forecasting of election outcomes. The overdispersion parameter \phiϕ helps in capturing extra variability in the polling data beyond the multinomial assumption.

sec.p: To assess the model’s fit, posterior predictive simulations are conducted:

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The dynamic linear model effectively captures the temporal evolution of party support and adjusts for polling house biases while accounting for overdispersion in the data. By leveraging Bayesian methods, we obtain a comprehensive probabilistic forecast of the election outcomes, accounting for uncertainty in the estimates.
